talk.author: did:plc:5djw6wywnxuqmfobsobh7flu
talk.utter: A lot of those sites either use Disqus which fits the description or have robust comments sections that require a sign-in, allow you to follow and block people and aren't "strictly for the purpose of email or direct messages."

talk.author: did:plc:5djw6wywnxuqmfobsobh7flu
talk.utter: "Substantial" is a pretty squishy word, probably for just this reason.

talk.author: did:plc:3ibec7zol6q5sz43zemvbgay
talk.utter: Maybe Disqus qualifies as that being a substantial part of their business, if not primary.  But, I don't really think of Disqus as legacy media.  I just know them as a comment manager, not as a newspaper itself.  And they wouldn't qualify under the law because they make less than $100M/yr.

talk.author: did:plc:3ibec7zol6q5sz43zemvbgay
talk.utter:
And I don't think online news outlets just having comment sections qualifies.  Plus, how many rake in that kind of money?

Laws can certainly be drafted poorly, but I imagine they spent some time deciding which companies will qualify, and were probably just targeting the very top social media ones.
